Situation1: The partner seems mildly stressed after a routine workday.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Story: I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of the day pressing on my shoulders. My partner had just texted, “Rough day. Can’t wait to see you.” I knew he needed me to listen, to be present, to offer comfort. That’s what he expected—what I wanted to give. But as I set my phone down, I caught the uncertain look of my new client in the mirror. She hesitated, running her fingers through her freshly coloured hair, her lips pressed into a thin line. “Is it… too warm?” she asked quietly. My heart squeezed. I needed to reassure her, to fix it if she wasn’t happy, to uphold my reputation as a professional who cares. But my mind kept drifting to my partner, waiting for me to come home and be his safe place. I felt split in two, torn between the urge to rush through the appointment and the duty to give my client the attention she deserved. My hands trembled slightly as I reached for the colour chart, my thoughts tangled in the impossible choice between being the girlfriend he needed and the hairdresser she expected.
